_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Arkalon facility in the past five years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:
The Arkalon ethanol plant has several safety programs in place at the facility that incorporate emergency response, including a Health and Safety Plan. Arkalon has evacuation and response procedures for fires, explosions, spills, etc. outlined in the facility Emergency Action Plan. The Plans listed as part of this Executive Summary have been prepared in accordance with the applicable regulations, as necessary.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:
Arkalon provides safety training to its employees and contractors on an annual basis. Any changes to improve safety will be implemented immediately upon discovery of needed changes.

hemical – Aqueous Ammonia: The alternative scenario used for anhydrous ammonia is a release of 49,064 pounds due to a tanker truck loadout spill, caused by a transfer hose failure, causing the liquid to pool and evaporate. This scenario is considered the most likely cause of an ammonia release onsite. The alternative release duration assumed is 10 minutes with an atmospheric stability of D and wind speed of 3.0 m/sec. The facility control room is manned 24 hours/day and would be alerted of the relief valve failure at the ammonia tank within minutes. No passive or active mitigation is considered in this scenario. RMP*Comp was used to determine the alternative distance to endpoint (1.0-mile radius); the model results are provided as part of this documentation. Population data was obtained using Circular Area Profiling Software (CAPS) which incorporates 2020 U.S. Census Data. Public receptor information (i.e., schools, hospitals, businesses, etc.) was obtained using Google Earth. No environmental receptors exist within the alternative distance to endpoint for aqueous ammonia.

Arkalon qualifies as a Program 3 level facility due to the presence of the flammable liquid that is covered by Process Safety Management (PSM) requirements, and as a Program 2 facility due to the presence of a listed Extremely Hazardous Substance.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:
Please review the first section of this Executive Summary for the general accidental release prevention program information.

Arkalon’s maintenance department performs regular preventative maintenance inspections, as required by the manufacturer's recommendations and/or State and Federal regulations. Monthly visual inspections are conducted, and monthly leak detection monitoring is performed, with associated reports filed per KDHE and/or EPA requirements.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:
There have been no reportable accidents associated with RMP covered processes at the

ank was originally designed to store anhydrous ammonia, Arkalon determined that the maximum volume of aqueous ammonia that could be stored in this tank is 13,705 gallons. For this worst-case scenario, it assumed that a catastrophic failure of the tank resulted in the release of 102,378 pounds, which equivalent to the maximum tank capacity of 13,705 gallons, using the specific gravity for 26° Baume aqueous ammonia, as stated on the Safety Data Sheet (SDS). A determination spreadsheet is included as part of this documentation detailing the conversion from gallons to pounds of aqueous ammonia. Since the toxic chemical is not stored in a diked area, no passive mitigation is assumed in the endpoint calculation. As required by the rule, it was assumed that the spill spreads out until a depth of one (1) centimeter (0.39 inch), and assuming the spill occurs onto a flat, not-absorbing surface. Since a release would likely be onto, in part, a somewhat porous surface (soil), the distance estimated may be overestimated. Guidance provided by EPA’s Risk Management Program Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis (March 2009) indicated that a ten (10) minute release rate for aqueous ammonia, a neutrally buoyant substance in both rural and urban environments was appropriate. RMP*Comp was used to determine the worst-case distance to endpoint (2.7-mile radius); the model results are also provided as part of this documentation. The highest daily maximum temperature (40 CFR 68.25(d)(2)) from the previous three (3) years was provided by the Midwestern Regional Climate Center cli-MATE application. Population data was obtained using Circular Area Profiling Software (CAPS), which incorporates 2020 U.S. Census Data. Public receptor information (i.e., schools, hospitals, businesses, etc.) was obtained using Google Earth. A local recreational area (Arkalon Park) is within the worst-case distance to endpoint for this aqueous ammonia scenario.

Aqueous Ammonia Alternative Scenario:

2.	Toxic C

NO environmental receptors are within the worst-case distance to endpoint for this scenario.

Flammable Alternative Scenario:

1.	NFPA 4 Flammable Mixture (Denaturant): The alternative scenario used for the flammable mixture is the release of 43,577 pounds of natural gasoline due to a transfer hose failure during a tanker truck loadout, causing a vapor cloud fire. The endpoint used was an over pressurization     of 1.0 pound per square inch (psi), a worst-case option. Denaturant deliveries at the facility typically occur during normal business hours with a facility staff member overseeing loadout operations – therefore a release at the loadout area could be ceased within minutes by manual overrides. The loadout area also has a catchment basin with underground piping to secondary containment of the tank farm. For this scenario passive and active mitigation was not considered, as the mitigation strategies currently in place would not contain a vapor cloud fire. RMP*Comp was used to determine the alternative distance to endpoint (0.1 miles); the model results are provided as part of this documentation. Population data was obtained using Circular Area Profiling Software (CAPS) which incorporates 2020 U.S. Census Data. Public receptor information (i.e., schools, hospitals, businesses, etc.) was obtained using Google Earth as well as the facility’s knowledge of nearby residences. CAPS only provides Census data at a radius of 0.4 miles or more. No public or environmental receptors would be affected by an alternative release of denaturant. 

Ammonia Worst Case Scenarios:

2.	Toxic Chemical - Aqueous Ammonia: Aqueous ammonia at 30% is to be stored in one (1) 18,000-gallon bullet tank outside northeast of the process building. Commercial grades of aqueous ammonia various from less than 20 weight-percent to 30-weight percent; 30-weight percent was selected for this evaluation since it has the highest vapor pressure of generally available commercial grades. While this bullet t

Seward County, Kansas. The facility operates 24 hours per day, 7 days per week to manufacture ethanol (fuel-, industrial-, or beverage-grade) from corn and/or milo. The regulated flammable substance under the RMP program is natural gasoline (denaturant). Pentane is the single largest constituent within Arkalon’s denaturant and was selected as the entire contents of the flammable liquid for RMP purposes. Arkalon also stores a regulated toxic substance, aqueous ammonia (>20%). The scenario analysis used aqueous ammonia at a concentration

WORST CASE AND ALTERNATIVE CASE SCENARIOS:
Flammable Worst-Case Scenarios:

1.	NFPA 4 Flammable Mixture (Denaturant): The flammable mixture stored onsite is natural gasoline, typically referred to as denaturant. Natural gasoline is used onsite to denature ethanol prior to shipment off site.  Denaturant is stored in a 200,000-gallon aboveground steel tank in the facility tank farm. The tank is located within a diked containment structure that contains an impermeable liner with gravel overlay. No passive mitigation was assumed to contain a worst-case release. The facility’s natural gasoline (denaturant) SDS was used to determine RMP applicability. The breakdown of reportable constituents is included as part of the determination documentation. The worst-case scenario used is the release of the entire contents of the denaturant tank, 1,146,750 pounds, causing a vapor cloud explosion. RMP*Comp was used to determine the worst-case distance to endpoint (0.8 miles); the model results are provided as part of this documentation. Population data was obtained using Circular Area Profiling Software (CAPS) which incorporates 2020 U.S. Census Data. Public receptor information (i.e., schools, hospitals, businesses, etc.) was obtained using Google Earth as well as the facility’s knowledge of nearby residences. A worst-case release would likely travel to the northeast, where it would be contained within natural topography inside the facility boundary.

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Arkalon Ethanol, LLC

Conestoga Energy Partners, LLC received a Construction Permit on October 17, 2006, to build and operate a fuel-grade ethanol production facility. Arkalon Ethanol, LLC is permitted to manufacture up to 121 million gallons of ethanol per year. The anniversary date of the most recent resubmission of the RMP was November 21, 2017.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES:
Arkalon has an ongoing commitment to the health and safety of onsite employees and the surrounding community. This commitment is demonstrated in the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training for the proper operation and maintenance of plant equipment and preventative maintenance programs.

Arkalon has emergency response policies in place that are addressed in the facility's Health and Safety Plan; Industrial Storm Water Pollution Prevention Plan; Spill Prevention, Controls, and Countermeasures Plan; Facility Response Plan; and Emergency Action Plan. Most of the listed Plans require a minimum of annual training in order to keep employees educated on emergency response procedures in place at the facility. All new employees are required to undergo training on emergency response procedures prior to initiating responsibilities onsite.

Arkalon’s policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, plant personnel will respond to contain the release as necessary.

The primary emergency coordinator for Arkalon is Richard Hanson, Plant Manager. His work and 24-hour emergency response telephone numbers are provided in the Registration Section of this document. The facility EH&S Manager also assists the Plant Manager with RMP and spill response coordination:

Chris Chaffin, EHS Manager
